caption: It's an interesting and solemn site of where many royalists died. Its also interesting how it writes and frames things focusing on the supposed tragedy with the events also being the basis of modern french identity.  Price is low and it's worth a look to complete a look into the revolutions; a fine hidden gem if you can withstand some monarchist leaning notes and visitors.

Can’t express how much I love this place. It’s totally beyond expectations! Petite indeed but tranquil and offering a sense of serenity. And I actually like the story of Marie-Thérèse Charlotte. Bringing a book or a sandwich and sitting in the surrounding park on a sunny afternoon is highly recommended. Oh, the staff are just kind and polite. I really did have a wonderful visit!

Nice and short little spot to learn a bit about the history of the revolution period and after, though hopefully you speak French, as a large portion of the signs at the end are only in French. There is a nice park right next to it with a water fountain!

A solemn, peaceful place to contemplate life and the tragedy of the Reign of Terror. Reading Marie-Antoinette's last letter to her sister-in-law (engraved on one of the walls) reduced me to tears. Only two other people were there besides myself - the tranquility of the chapel belies the violent events commemorated here. Definitely worth a detour off the beaten track.

I read some of the comments on Google Maps that criticised the money paid for the little there seemingly is to see. Well, some of the reviewers weren't clearly paying attention. This is a place for contemplation and a place full of significance for a period of the history of France and Europe when enlightened monarchs saw their authority questioned and died at the guillotine. The importance of the place is further added by the fact that only in the early 20th century did the authorities finally put aside the idea of having it demolished. The architecture, the symbolism, are both beautiful.
Chapel of French royalists, reminder of French Revolution and a little park around it. Pay attention to the nice building next to it with reliefs of animals on the facade. Beautiful.

Place where Luis XVIII wish to remember the death of Luis XVI and Marie-Antoinette during the French Revolution. To be visited only if you have free time spare. Architectural    particular interesting as the "winged hourglass"
A very quiet and interesting place. The exhibition was very informative.
Hidden gem of Paris. The chapel was built on the first graveyard that hosted the bodies of King Louis XVI and Marie-Antoniette.

Nice but small chapel to visit in case you're interested in this sort of thing. A little expensive for what it actually offers. A small central chapel and its history in a bunch of text billboards in French.
A nice part of sightseeing..not very crowded You can a have a relaxing time at the garden and park outside
Quiet and beautiful space. Be aware there are no public restrooms.
For those younger than 26 years entrance is free
Beautiful church ? I guess ? Or maybe national monument ? Good scenario for pictures !
Nice place to rest after running throughout all Lafayette and Printemps galeries. Nice suny place at 5.30pm
Peaceful haven in the middle of Paris. Sit down with a coffee and enjoy the park's atmosphere.

A MUST SEE site in your Paris experience. To understand why this monument was created, is to better appreciate the horrors of the Revolution, and therefore to more fully appreciate your stay in Paris.  It’s a sobering moment — one that’s really very grounding, contextualizing, and eye opening.
Absolutely beautiful chapelle!
La Chapelle expiatoire is a fantastic oasis of calm in this busy city. The little park is lovely, the Chapelle architecture striking, and it's an unexpected, interesting bit of history.
Does not worth visit and 6 €
Nothing special.Just if you are a history lover it worths the visit.The google visit schedule needs an update.It's not accurate.
Very good church, a building combining modern and traditional style

Very interesting little visit. It's fairly short as the only remaining artefact are the supposed tombs of louis xvi and Marie Antoinette. There is also the testament from louis xvi and a letter that Marie Antoinette wrote to her sister before their deaths. Shockingly none of both seem to understand the reason for their deaths.
A perfect historical location for a wedding or elopement ceremony. Beautuful chapelle with a nice garden

I stubbled upon the chapel by accident. I guess it's more of a local French thing than for tourists, there wasn't much to see. I got in free, so it didn't matter that much, but I wouldn't go there if I had to pay for the place.
Great quiet place for a short escape from the crowds
6 Euro for essentially nothing.  Very small, nothing of substance and architecture and gardens were underwhelming.
Very old chapel.  Worth a visit if in the area.
Is a little beautiful place, people is so kindly en the shop ;)
Way too expensive for what it is
Beautiful architecture.
Quiet and beautiful, short visit but definitely worth it
Beautiful yet simple Chapel, interesting story surrounding the place
Expnesive for a student
Small but strong!
Top.
Suggestive place
Beautiful chapel
